title: Complementary Colors

hook.text: Red and green. Blue and orange. Yellow and purple. Colors directly opposite on the wheel create the strongest contrast possible. They're visual rivals that make each other POP.

buildup.text: Complementary colors intensify each other when placed side by side. Red looks redder next to green. Blue looks bluer next to orange. They create vibrant, energetic combinations.

discovery.text: But mixed together, complements neutralize each other into gray or brown. This is incredibly useful: add a touch of complement to tone down an overly vivid color without changing its hue.

twist.text: Too much complementary contrast vibrates and becomes visually painful â€” like red text on a green background. The trick is to use one as dominant and the other as an accent.

climax.text: Monet's haystacks use orange light against blue-purple shadows â€” a complementary scheme. The shadows vibrate with color instead of looking muddy.

punchline.text: Opposites attract â€” and vibrate. Use complements for maximum impact.

quiz.question: What happens when complementary colors are mixed together?
options: They neutralize into gray or brown
